NPC: Hi! I'm Had, who are you?

Choices.Player: I can't remember my name. But there are worse things than forgetfulness. Had!
I remember nothing.

NPC: That can't be true! You must remember something.

Choices.Player: You're right. There's definitely something here. Perhaps I need to relax my definition of a thing.

Not people but words. Words I've recalled again and again. Descendants of words once spoken. My many faux pas! Other those the time I got the last word in with that braggart! And the blithe bruising words of that manipulatrix!
Why? The only thing I ever had in common with others is a desire for my non-existence.

NPC: There must have been more people. What about the faux pas?

Choices.Player: I spent my life perfecting the solitary faux pas.
I mostly embarrassed myself in private. Where others were involved, all I could tell you now is the type, colour and condition of their shoes.

NPC: Can you give me an example?

Choices.Player: I held a belief about which I was uncertain. About the contents of another's mind, or underwear. Then I thought that a good God, a loving God, would never plonk an erroneous thought in my skull. I must therefore have been right.
There was a time I could move my arm â€“ well enough to attend to myself at least.

NPC: Have you written these aphorisms down?

Choices.Player: Only a truly despicable person would commit such a thing to writing!
My magnum opus!. You can find copies in three national libraries.
Good. Where were we?

NPC: Before the all that business with your memory, I think we'd just met.

Choices.Player: [You are silent.]
[You remain silent.]
Well, where does that leave us?
I'd been brusque. I could feel her eyes boring into my back. She wouldn't leave until I turned my chair. So I did, eighteen degrees at a time.

NPC: I think our only option is to leave this place.

Choices.Player: Yes let's leave. How do we get out?

NPC: There's an opening to this room, but I can't see where it leads.

Choices.Player: Try to find out. I'm not yet willing to take just any door. Things can always be worse.

NPC: Actually, now that I look closer, the door seems to lead into a tunnel.

Choices.Player: Where might the tunnel lead, can you see any light?
Doesn't it? Well, I'm willing to take the chance.

NPC: I suppose we'll eventually starve here. Let's go.

Choices.Player: You'll need to push me out of the door.
Are we out of the room yet? I can still hear the buzzing.
Have we left the room yet?

NPC: Not yet. I've got a few  things to do.

Choices.Player: Let's get out of this room. There's nothing for us here.

NPC: I'm not sure I want to hear this.

Choices.Player: Very well.
Bear with me! The onanism is only incidental.

NPC: What happened to the other copies?

Choices.Player: Pulped!
The publishers said there wasn't a market.
After that I remember staring at her bare ankles. Not her face. Nothing else.
I saw her face for an imperceptible instant. Livid. My gaze shot to her feet., like an insect shocked by sudden movement . All I remember from then on is her bare ankles. They were remarkably thin.
I don't know what she did or when she left. Shame carved a hole in my memory. When I try to push though, it is as thought I've caught hold of my own viscera
A flashbulb, Something hard struck the side of my head. That's all I remember.

NPC: Sounds painful. I don't think I want to hear any more. Let's talk about the matter at hand.

Choices.Player: Sorry, I don't know why I'm telling you this.
Well? You asked about my memories.
[You hold your tongue.]
I wondered how such a thing as my mind, which I could not measure with a ruler, could cause the excitation of such a thing as my member, which I could.

Then I realised that it was all very simple. Everything was composed of simple indivisible things. My mind was one such thing, that perceived with some degree of clarity. My hand was composed of of a multitude of less clear things, murky ponds full of dimwitted fish.

The crux of it was that none of these things interacted. They just appeared to do so. They moved independently on a course predetermined by God. This was an immense relief. That a man slumped in a chair should attend to himself in such a manner was simply a matter of course! It could be no other way, and my mind had as much choice in the matter as my hand.
Yes, but it gave me solace while I beleived it.
Beautiful in a way, but definitely a false step in my reasoning.
I suppose I could have chosen more pleasant memory.
Don't get me started on aesthetics! There's plenty more where that came from.

NPC: Well that's what's important. Let's talk about something else.
